citation.article-title: Isolation and Characterization of Clostridium stercorarium sp. nov., Cellulolytic Thermophile

p.s: Description of Clostridium stercorarium sp. nov.
Clostridium stercorarium (L. adj. stercorarium pertaining to dung, referring to the source of the isolate, a compost heap)
Cells are straight rods 0.7 to 0.8 by 2.7 to 7.7 μm and are motile and peritrichous (Fig. 1 ).
Endospores are oval and terminal.
Vegetative cells decolorize readily and usually stain gram negative.
Colonies in cellulose agar are lenticular, unpigmented. and 1 to 2 mm in diameter.
After incubation for 7 days, colonies are surrounded by clear zones, representing cellulose hydrolysis, that usually are 3 to 5 mm in diameter.
Upon continued incubation the colonies become cream colored.
Surface colonies on cellobiose agar are 3 to 5 mm in diameter, glossy, not pigmented, and umbonate.
The raised centers of the colonies are cream colored, and the margins are flat, entire, and colorless.
Optimum growth is obtained at 65°C and near pH 7.3.
Growth at 60 or 70°C is approximately 60% of that obtained at 65°C.
The mean generation time for cultures grown in cellulose broth at 65°C is 16 h.
Only slight growth occurs in nutrient broth without fermentable carbohydrate.
With a fermentable carbohydrate cultures are moderately turbid, with a smooth sediment.
The pH of cellobiose broths is 4.8 after incubation for 2 days.
Other characteristics of the species are given in Table 1.
The mean pH of uninoculated media was 6.81.
The mean pH of the media considered not to have been fermented was 6.62, the reduction in pH probably being due to the fermentation of cellobiose transferred with the inoculum.
A value of pH 6.0 was chosen to indicate growth, and the mean pH of cultures showing growth was 5.77; hence, growth was indicated by a decrease in pH of approximately 0.8 U.
Fermentation products in glucose broths were ethanol, acetate, lactate, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide.
About 4 mM acetate, 4 mM ethanol, and less than 1 mM lactate were found in typical cultures.
Endoglucanase, exoglucanase, and xylanase are produced in cellulose broths (la) .
Approximately 60% of the endoglucanase activity is produced after growth has ceased (J.-F.
Berenger and N .
Creuzet, unpublished data).
Isolated from a compost heap.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the deoxyribonucleic acid is 39 mol%, as determined by the melting temperature method.
The type strain is National Collection of Industrial Bacteria strain NCIB 11754.
